citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Two adult babydoll sheep and four other adult sheep are in need of shearing. The sheep have thick wooly coats covering
much of their body. The sheep were noticed to be panting. The temperature at time of inspection was 88 degrees
Fahrenheit with high humidity . Sheep who have thick wooly coats in hot weather may experience heat stress, heat
stroke, and discomfort.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
There are rat holes around and under the primate enclosure housing two grivets and six ring-tailed lemurs.
Pests can harbor diseases that are transmitted directly to the animals or may contaminate feed or water which could
make the animals sick.
An effective program for control of insects, external parasites affecting nonhuman primates, and birds and mammals that
are pests, must be established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce
contamination by pests in animal areas.

-There are rat holes noted under and around the primary enclosure for the two African Crested porcupines and the two
capybaras. The licensee stated they have tried rat traps but it hasn’t been effective.
Pests can harbor diseases that are transmitted directly to the animals or may contaminate feed or water which could
make the animals sick.
A safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests shall be
established and maintained. This requirement includes but, is not limited to, an effective method to control rats as pests.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
There is a wasp nest in the eves of the primary enclosure for a single young emu, one call duck, and two young black
swans.
Biting insects can cause pain, discomfort and possibly an allergic reaction from their bite.
A safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests must be
established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the birds and reduce contamination by pests in
animal areas. Insecticides, chemical agents, or other pest control products that may be harmful to the birds must not be
applied to primary enclosures and other bird contact surfaces unless the application is consistent with manufacturer
recommendations or otherwise approved for use and does not harm birds.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class "C" license.
The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by August 17, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply.
Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
Two adult babydoll sheep and four other adult sheep are in need of shearing. The sheep have thick wooly coats covering 
much of their body. The sheep were noticed to be panting. The temperature at time of inspection was 88 degrees 
Fahrenheit with high humidity . Sheep who have thick wooly coats in hot weather may experience heat stress, heat 
stroke, and discomfort. 
3.84(d)  Repeat
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
There are rat holes around and under the primate enclosure housing two grivets and six ring-tailed lemurs. 
Pests can harbor diseases that are transmitted directly to the animals or may contaminate feed or water which could 
make the animals sick.  
An effective program for control of insects, external parasites affecting nonhuman primates, and birds and mammals that 
are pests, must be established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the animals and reduce 
contamination by pests in animal areas. 
3.131(d)  Repeat
   
Sanitation. 
-There are rat holes noted under and around the primary enclosure for the two African Crested porcupines and the two 
capybaras. The licensee stated they have tried rat traps but it hasn’t been effective. 
Pests can harbor diseases that are transmitted directly to the animals or may contaminate feed or water which could 
make the animals sick.  
A safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests shall be 
established and maintained. This requirement includes but, is not limited to, an effective method to control rats as pests. 
3.158(d) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
There is a wasp nest in the eves of the primary enclosure for a single young emu, one call duck, and two young black 
swans. 
Biting insects can cause pain, discomfort and possibly an allergic reaction from their bite.

A safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests must be 
established and maintained so as to promote the health and well-being of the birds and reduce contamination by pests in 
animal areas. Insecticides, chemical agents, or other pest control products that may be harmful to the birds must not be 
applied to primary enclosures and other bird contact surfaces unless the application is consistent with manufacturer 
recommendations or otherwise approved for use and does not harm birds. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class "C" license.  
The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspection(s) or by August 17, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply.  
Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
